The Group of Twenty
The Elder Nun Rohinī’s Verses
“You dream of ‘monks’,
and you wake up thinking ‘monks’.
You praise the monks,
so you must be a monk yourself.🔽You give the monks
food and drink in abundance.
Now I ask you, Rohinī,
why do you love the monks?”

analyzed: a kamma kāmāḥ alasāḥ  para dattu upajīvinaḥ
translated: “They don’t want to work, they’re lazy,🔽they live off the gifts of others.
They’re greedy and lustful.
Why do you love the monks?”
“For a long time, dear,
you’ve been asking about the monks.
I’ll tell you about them,
their virtue, morality, and effort.
They want to work, they’re not lazy,
they do what’s best for their work.
They give up greed and hate.

original: tena me samaṇā piyā.🔽Tīṇi pāpassa mūlāni,🔽dhunanti sucikārino;

translated: That’s why I love the monks.🔽They shake off the three roots of what’s unskillful,🔽and they’re very clean.
They’ve given up all evil.
That’s why I love the monks.
Their bodily action is pure,
and their verbal action is likewise.
Their mental action is pure.
That’s why I love the monks.🔽They’re spotless like a conch shell,
pure inside and out.
They are full of bright qualities,
that’s why I love the ascetics.
They are learned and remember what they’ve learned,
they’re noble and live by the Teaching.
They teach the meaning and the Teaching,
that’s why I love the ascetics.
They are learned and remember what they’ve learned,
they’re noble and live by the Teaching.
They’re one-pointed and mindful,
that’s why I love the ascetics.
They’re faring well and mindful,
they speak with composure and are not restless.
They understand the end of suffering,
that’s why I love the ascetics.
They leave the village
without looking back.
They go on without concern,
that’s why I love the ascetics.
They don’t store up in a basket,
a pot, or a bag.

that’s why I love the ascetics.
They don’t take gold,

They live on what they’ve been given,
that’s why I love the ascetics.
They’ve gone forth from various families,
from various countries.
They love each other,
that’s why I love the ascetics.”
“They’re truly for our benefit,
You were born into a good family, Rohinī.
You have faith in the Buddha, the Teaching,
and the Sangha, and you have great respect for them.
You know that this is the unsurpassed field of merit
where a gift is very fruitful.

original: Amhampi ete samaṇā,🔽paṭigaṇhanti dakkhiṇaṁ.🔽Patiṭṭhito hettha yañño,
analyzed: ete samaṇā  paṭigaṇhanti dakkhiṇa  patiṭṭhitaḥ ha ittha yaññaḥ
translated: These monastics accept our offerings.
Our sacrifice will be extensive and will last a long time.”
“If you fear suffering,
if you don’t like suffering,
Then go for refuge to the Buddha,
to the Teaching, and to the Sangha.
Take up the precepts,
and that will be for your benefit.”
“I go for refuge to the Buddha,
to the Teaching, and to the Sangha.
I take up the precepts,
and that will be for my benefit.
In the past I was a friend of the gods,
but now I am a brahmin.
I am skilled in the three Vedas,
a master of the Vedas, a bath-completed brahmin.”
… the nun Rohinī …
